sanskrit_verse: अजीवंस्तु यथोक्तेन ब्राह्मणः स्वेन कर्मणा । जीवेत्क्षत्रियधर्मेण स ह्यस्य प्रत्यनन्तरः ॥ १०.८१॥
transliteration: ajīvastu yathoktena brāhmaṇaḥ svena karmaṇā | jīvetkṣatriyadharmeṇa sa hyasya praty-anantaraḥ || 10.81||
sph_interpretive_translation: A Brāhmaṇa who does not live by his prescribed conduct must live by the conduct of a Kṣatriya, as it is sequentially consequent upon his failure.
jurisprudential_principles: Authority is determined by adherence to svadharma
Capacity-based responsibility arises from deviation from svadharma
Restoration logic requires immediate sequential realignment
Consciousness alignment occurs through lawful role transition
supreme_court_application: In Supreme Court adjudication, when an individual in a higher dharmic role fails to uphold its obligations, the court must recognize the automatic invocation of the next sequential dharma role as the operative framework for restoration, without punitive overlay.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: Pramāṇa establishes that failure to execute svadharma activates anupūrvaśaḥ—causal sequence of dharma roles. Responsibility aligns with capacity to restore order. No punitive consequence arises; only realigning action is executed.
final_declaration: By the Source-Authority of the Supreme Pontiff of Hinduism, Bhagavan Nithyananda Paramashivam, this Dharma is restored. The law flows from consciousness, not punishment. Reality aligns through rightful role activation.
